name: Portland, ME
tagline: Coastal New England charm—lobster rolls, lighthouses, and limited diversity

diversity.summary: FRIENDLY BUT ISOLATING: Maine is the whitest state after Vermont, and you will feel it. Reddit: "You will absolutely deal with racism in two forms." BUT people also say "the level of friendliness made up for it" and "it's v rare for someone to call you a slur—they don't do that here much." The racism is covert: microaggressions, being tokenized in professional settings, feeling like an outsider, struggling to find community. Portland itself is trying—Black Art and Experiences Gallery at Portland Museum of Art, growing immigrant population. It's not hostile, just overwhelmingly white. Candace would be lonely.
diversity.diversity_index: ~85% White, 7% Black, 4% Asian, 5% Hispanic (whitest state in America after Vermont)
diversity.notable: Maine = whitest state; covert racism (tokenization, microaggressions) not overt slurs; friendly but isolating; hard to find Black community

safety.summary: Portland is one of the safest cities on this list. Crime is low overall, with property crime being the main concern (car break-ins in touristy areas). Violent crime is rare. Small city feel contributes to safety. Most neighborhoods are very safe.

scenery.summary: Coastal New England beauty—Casco Bay, lighthouses, rocky coastline, islands. Fall foliage is spectacular. Winter snow on the harbor is postcard-perfect. Access to both ocean and mountains (White Mountains 1.5 hours). Quintessential Maine scenery.

climate.summary: Four true seasons with real New England winter—61 inches of snow and cold temps. Beautiful mild summers and stunning fall colors, but winter is genuine. Ocean moderates temperatures slightly but this is still cold. Gray days common. Not for warm-weather preference.

culture.summary: Portland is a foodie destination—James Beard Award winners, incredible seafood (lobster, oysters), farm-to-table ethos, craft beer and distilleries. Arts scene is strong for its size. Indie bookstores, galleries, music venues. Feels cultured and authentic but SMALL—you'll know the city intimately within months.

pros: Extremely safe—one of the safest cities on this list
Beautiful coastal scenery and access to ocean
Excellent food scene (seafood, farm-to-table, James Beard restaurants)
Four seasons with New England charm
Small city charm—easy to navigate and get to know
cons: ⚠️ CRITICAL: Maine's whitest major city—Candace may feel very isolated
BIPOC residents report difficulty integrating and unequal access
Very small—will feel limiting after 1-2 years
BRUTAL winter (real New England cold and snow)
Expensive for a small city (tourism drives costs)
saturday: You wake up in Munjoy Hill to fog rolling off Casco Bay and walk to Tandem Coffee for the best espresso in New England (locals swear by it). The morning is spent wandering the Old Port's cobblestone streets, browsing bookstores and maritime shops. Lunch is lobster rolls at Eventide Oyster Co (James Beard-winning), then you drive to Portland Head Light—the iconic lighthouse framed against rocky coastline. By evening, you're back for dinner at Duckfat (Belgian fries and poutine) or Fore Street (wood-fired everything). Portland is beautiful, quaint, foodie-friendly, and brutally white. You'd know every restaurant within a month. Charming, but small.

food_scene.summary: Portland, Maine is a legitimate foodie destination—James Beard Award winners, exceptional seafood, and a farm-to-table scene that rivals cities 10x its size. The city takes its food seriously. Mediterranean options are limited due to size, but quality is high across the board.
farmers_markets: Portland Farmers Market (Saturdays year-round, Deering Oaks Park)
food_scene.food_culture: Portland's food culture is seafood-first—lobster, oysters, clams, scallops from the Gulf of Maine. Duckfat, Fore Street, Eventide, and Central Provisions have won James Beard awards. The city's small size concentrates talent, and locals are passionate about eating well. Limited ethnic diversity, though, means international options are sparse.
food_scene.grocery_quality: Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, Rosemont Market (local, beloved), Hannaford. Solid grocery access for the size, strong local/organic focus, but limited international markets.

neighborhoods.name: Old Port
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Most walkable, beautiful, near everything. Touristy. Great for short-term but may feel isolating long-term.

neighborhoods.name: West End
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Slightly more diverse (still very white), progressive
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, beautiful architecture, residential feel. Safest bet for diversity in Portland (low bar).

neighborhoods.name: Munjoy Hill (East End)
neighborhoods.vibe: Artistic, eclectic, views of Casco Bay—Portland's bohemian side
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, character, views. Best option for diversity/acceptance in Portland. Still very white overall.

neighborhoods.name: East Bayside
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Most diverse option. Developing. May offer best sense of community but small scale. Gentrification tensions.

neighborhoods.name: Deering Center
neighborhoods.vibe: Residential, suburban feel within city limits
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Safe, affordable, less walkable. Not recommended—too suburban and homogeneous for their goals.
